natural problem: What is the remainder when $13^{51}$ is divided by 5?
natural solution: Note that  $13^{51}$ is $(10 + 3)^{51}$. Any term in the expansion that involves the 10 will be 0 modulo 5, so it suffices to consider $3^{51} \pmod{5}$.

We look for a pattern in powers of 3. \begin{align} 3^1 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 3^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 3^3 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 3^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $3^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $3^{51} \equiv 3^3 \cdot (3^4)^{12} \equiv 2 \pmod{5},$ hence our desired remainder is $\boxed{2}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 13 ^ 51"
shows  "n mod 5 = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $13^{51}$ is divided by 5? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Note that  $13^{51}$ is $(10 + 3)^{51}$. Any term in the expansion that involves the 10 will be 0 modulo 5, so it suffices to consider $3^{51} \pmod{5}$.
 We look for a pattern in powers of 3. \begin{align} 3^1 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 3^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 3^3 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 3^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $3^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $3^{51} \equiv 3^3 \cdot (3^4)^{12} \equiv 2 \pmod{5},$ hence our desired remainder is $\boxed{2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 13 ^ 51"
shows  "n mod 5 = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the remainder when $13^{51}$ is divided by 5. The final answer is 2.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 13 powr 51"
shows  "x mod 5 = 2"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $13^{51}$ is divided by 5? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Note that  $13^{51}$ is $(10 + 3)^{51}$. Any term in the expansion that involves the 10 will be 0 modulo 5, so it suffices to consider $3^{51} \pmod{5}$.
 We look for a pattern in powers of 3. \begin{align} 3^1 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 3^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 3^3 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 3^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $3^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $3^{51} \equiv 3^3 \cdot (3^4)^{12} \equiv 2 \pmod{5},$ hence our desired remainder is $\boxed{2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 13 powr 51"
shows  "x mod 5 = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the remainder when $13^{51}$ is divided by $5$. The final answer is $2$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. (13 ^ n) mod 5 = (2 :: nat)"
shows  "(13 ^ 51) mod 5 = 2"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $13^{51}$ is divided by 5? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Note that  $13^{51}$ is $(10 + 3)^{51}$. Any term in the expansion that involves the 10 will be 0 modulo 5, so it suffices to consider $3^{51} \pmod{5}$.
 We look for a pattern in powers of 3. \begin{align} 3^1 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 3^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 3^3 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 3^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $3^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $3^{51} \equiv 3^3 \cdot (3^4)^{12} \equiv 2 \pmod{5},$ hence our desired remainder is $\boxed{2}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. (13 ^ n) mod 5 = (2 :: nat)"
shows  "(13 ^ 51) mod 5 = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: For any natural number n, the remainder when 13 to the power of n is divided by 5 is always 2. What is the remainder when 13 to the power of 51 is divided by 5? The final answer is 2.

a_3.formal problem:

assumes h0 : "n = 13 powr 51 mod 5"
shows  "n = 2"

 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 13 powr 51 mod 5"
shows  "n = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: "What is the remainder when $13^{51}$ is divided by 5? The final answer is 2."

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z :: int
assumes h0 : "x = 13 powr 51"
and h1 : "y = 5"
and h2 : "z = x mod y"
shows  "z = 2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the remainder when $13^{51}$ is divided by 5? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 Note that  $13^{51}$ is $(10 + 3)^{51}$. Any term in the expansion that involves the 10 will be 0 modulo 5, so it suffices to consider $3^{51} \pmod{5}$.
 We look for a pattern in powers of 3. \begin{align} 3^1 &\equiv 3 \pmod{5} \\ 3^2 &\equiv 4 \pmod{5} \\ 3^3 &\equiv 2 \pmod{5} \\ 3^4 &\equiv 1 \pmod{5}. \end{align}Since $3^4 \equiv 1 \pmod{5},$ we see that $3^{51} \equiv 3^3 \cdot (3^4)^{12} \equiv 2 \pmod{5},$ hence our desired remainder is $\boxed{2}.$
 *)

fixes x y z :: int
assumes h0 : "x = 13 powr 51"
and h1 : "y = 5"
and h2 : "z = x mod y"
shows  "z = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
